groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p><i>Understanding Society</i>, or the <i>United Kingdom Household Longitudinal Study</i> (UKHLS), is conducted by the Institute for Social and Economic Research (ISER), at the University of Essex. The survey research organisation in Great Britain is NatCen Social Research and in Northern Ireland, the Central Survey Unit of the Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency (NISRA).<br> <br> As a multi-topic household survey, the purpose of <i>Understanding Society</i> is to understand social and economic change in Britain at the household and individual levels. It is anticipated that over time the study will permit examination of short- and long-term effects of social and economic change, including policy interventions, on the general well-being of the UK population with a strong emphasis on domains of family and social ties, work, financial resources, and health. The study is an annual survey of each adult member of a nationally representative sample. The same individuals are re-interviewed in each wave. If individuals leave their household, all adult members of their new household are interviewed. Each wave is collected over 24 months, such that the first wave of data was collected between January 2009 and January 2011, the second wave between January 2010 and January 2012, and so forth. Data collection takes place using computer assisted personal interviewing (CAPI). One person completes the household questionnaire. Each person aged 16 or older answers the individual adult interview and self-completion questionnaire. Young people aged 10-15 years are asked to respond to a paper self-completion questionnaire.<br> <br> The study has four sample components:  the General Population component, the Innovation Panel, a boost sample of ethnic minority group members, and participants in the former <i>British Household Panel Survey</i> (BHPS) (held at the UK Data Archive under SN 5151). Waves 1-2 (SN 6614) include the General Population component and the ethnic minority boost sample. The Innovation Panel data are held separately under SN 6849. Former participants of the BHPS joined <i>Understanding Society</i> from Wave 2. BHPS sample members have an identifier within the <i>Understanding Society</i> datasets from Wave 2 onwards, allowing the matching of BHPS data to <i>Understanding Society</i>.<br> <br> Further information about the survey may be found on the <a href="http://www.understandingsociety.ac.uk/" title="Understanding Society">Understanding Society</a> web site.<br> <br> <b>End User Licence and Special Licence <i>Understanding Society</i> data:</b><br> Users should note that there are two versions of the main <i>Understanding Society</i> data. One is available under the standard End User Licence (EUL) agreement, and the other is a Special Licence (SL) version. The SL version contains month and year of birth variables instead of just age, more detailed country and occupation coding for a number of variables and various income variables have not been top-coded (see the documentation available with the SL version for more detail on the differences). Users are advised to first obtain the standard EUL version of the data to see if they are sufficient for their research requirements. The SL data have more restrictive access conditions; prospective users of the SL version will need to complete an extra application form and demonstrate to the data owners exactly why they need access to the additional variables in order to get permission to use that version. <br> <br> <i>Special Licence files currently available:</i><br> - The SL versions of the main <i>Understanding Society</i> and Innovation Panel studies may be found under SNs 6931 and 7083 respectively.<br> - Low-level and Medium-level Geographical Identifiers data are also available subject to SL access conditions; see SNs 6666, 6668-6675 and 7182 (main study) and 6908-6916 (Innovation Panel).<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract>The <i>Understanding Society: Interviewer Survey 2014</i> data file is the output of a research project that collected information from interviewers who worked on the Understanding Society data collection for Great Britain in the first round of interviews, which took place over the course of the years 2009 and 2010. <br> <br> One of the specific aims of the data collection was to better understand the nature of bias in respondent consent to data linkage and, in particular, the role of interviewers in obtaining consent and in affecting consent bias. Hence, the interviewer survey includes a number of questions eliciting interviewer attitudes to consent to data linkage and their experiences with asking for consent during the fieldwork. There are, however, also a great deal of questions that will be of interest to a greater audience of researchers, such as interviewer attitudes to persuasion, measures of their personality traits and markers of general trust.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The dataset included the following topics:<br> <ul><li>interviewers' opinions on their job</li><li>attitudes to persuasion, surveys in general</li><li>personality traits and trust</li><li>data privacy and administration of Understanding Society</li><li>experience asking for consent to link to administrative data</li><li>usefulness of linked data and their own likelihood of consent to linked data in different domains</li></ul><br> </abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2014-05-01T00:00:00Z">May 2014</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2014-05-01T00:00:00Z">May 2014</collDate>         <nation>England and Wales</nation>         <nation>Scotland</nation>         <geogUnit>No spatial unit</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Families/households</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit>Survey interviewers</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>All interviewers in England, Scotland and Wales.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>         <dataKind> Alpha/numeric data</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Cross-sectional (one-time) study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Longitudinal/panel/cohort</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>NatCen Social Research</dataCollector>         <dataCollector>Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency.
